articles.title: Ephemeris January 83
articles.summary: This article, titled "Ephemeris January 83," outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) event schedule for January and February 1983. It details various star parties, indoor sessions for telescope activities, board and general meetings featuring speakers like Norm Sperling on "Landsat" and Don Machholz on the Messier Marathon, and notes astronomical phenomena like New and Full Moons.

articles.title: Observations
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is undergoing several significant changes for the new year, including a move to a new general meeting site at the University of Santa Clara, replacing DeAnza College, which offers improved facilities and a new agreement to support astronomy classes. The January meeting will feature speaker Norm Sperling, formerly of Sky & Telescope, discussing Earth observations from the Landsat satellite. Additionally, Jack Zeiders will take over as the new bulletin editor, promising a revamped format for the club's newsletter, and the article notes an adjusted meeting schedule to avoid observing conflicts while soliciting content for future issues.

articles.title: Future meetings:
articles.summary: The article outlines a series of upcoming astronomical events and meetings. January features a telescope alignment clinic by Bob Fingerhut and the WAA Winter Board Meeting where the G. Bruce Blair Medal winner will be chosen. February includes a film night with "The Observatories" and NASA films, followed by an indoor star party with Don Machholz preparing attendees for the Messier Marathon. The Messier Marathon itself is scheduled for two weekends in March at Loma Prieta.

articles.title: SEE YOU THERE!
articles.summary: The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) is reviving its "Question of the Month" column for January to survey members on whether the club's bulletin should accept commercial astronomical advertising. The board is seeking member input to guide its decision, considering potential benefits like funding for the bulletin and observatory site against drawbacks such as reduced space for member-contributed content. Members should expect to be approached for their opinion via phone or at meetings.

articles.title: DIRECTIONS (Basic)
articles.summary: This document provides basic directions for reaching a meeting location from both north and south on Hwy 17, including specific exits and turns. It mentions notable local landmarks and details the meeting spot as the Alumni Science Hall, tentatively room 102, with ample parking available.

articles.title: Comet Comments
articles.summary: As 1983 begins, Don Machholz's "Comet Comments" notes one visible comet and a quiet 1982 for new discoveries. The column introduces a new segment analyzing past comet discoveries, specifically focusing on pre-discovery data to understand why amateur-discovered comets between 1975-1982 weren't found earlier. Machholz details his method of plotting and graphing pre-discovery positions and magnitudes, a practice used by comet hunters to refine their search techniques.

articles.title: PERIODIC COMET CHURYUMOV-GERASIMENKO (1982f)
articles.summary: This document provides an observing report for Periodic Comet Churyumov-Gerasimenko (1982f), detailing its celestial coordinates, magnitude, and appearance from late 1982 to early 1983. Additionally, it offers a detailed historical account of the 1975 discovery of Comet Boethin (1975a) by Rev. Leo Boethin, including the discovery circumstances, orbital characteristics, and a mention of another astronomer who nearly discovered it.

articles.title: TALES OF THE WORKSHOP, #147
articles.summary: This installment of "Tales of the Workshop" details the challenges and traditions of telescope mirror making, highlighting the pervasive influence of Murphy's Law. The author recounts his and Bob Fingebrut's six-month journey of grinding, polishing, and battling zones on their respective 14-inch and 8-inch mirrors, eventually achieving sixth-wave and eighth-wave results. The piece emphasizes the camaraderie and shared experience within the telescope makers' workshop community, culminating in a celebratory Dr. Pepper float at Denny's.

articles.title: Veara pass:
articles.summary: This article recounts the arduous and often humorous journey of Denni Frerichs and Bob during 1981-82, as they independently yet synchronously worked to grind and polish a 16-inch and an 18-5/8 inch telescope mirror. They faced numerous technical challenges, mishaps, and moments of despair, from mirror damage to problems with pitch laps and achieving the correct parabolic figure. Despite setbacks and a shared realization that neither could finish until the other did, both mirrors were successfully completed through perseverance, culminating in a celebration with Dr. Pepper floats.
